Complete Blood Count (CBC): Leukopenia (low white blood cell count), anemia, thrombocytopenia (low platelet count).
Liver Function Tests (ALT, AST, ALP, Bil: Elevated liver enzymes or bilirubin indicating hepatotoxicity.
Renal Function Tests (Creatinine, BUN): Elevated levels indicating nephrotoxicity, particularly with aminoglycosides or vancomycin.
Electrolytes (Potassium, Sodium, Magnesi: Imbalances such as hypokalemia or hypomagnesemia, especially with amphotericin B or diuretics used concurrently.
Prothrombin Time (PT) / INR: Prolonged clotting times, particularly with cephalosporins interfering with vitamin K metabolism.
Coagulation Tests (aPTT, D-dimer): Abnormal clotting parameters, occasionally seen with antibiotics affecting coagulation pathways.
Blood Glucose: Hypoglycemia or hyperglycemia, reported with certain fluoroquinolones like gatifloxacin.
Urinalysis: Proteinuria, hematuria, or crystals in the urine, indicating renal involvement.
Amylase and Lipase: Elevated levels indicating possible pancreatitis (e.g., tetracyclines or sulfonamides).
C-Reactive Protein (CRP) / Erythrocyte S: Decreased inflammatory markers due to suppression of infection; may also be unaffected depending on context.
Creatine Kinase (CK): Elevated levels indicating myopathy or rhabdomyolysis, potentially caused by daptomycin or other agents.
Lactic Acid: Elevated levels due to mitochondrial toxicity or impaired oxygen utilization.
Antinuclear Antibodies (ANA): Positive results linked to drug-induced lupus-like syndrome, particularly with minocycline or other antibiotics.
Blood Culture: False negatives if antibiotics are administered before sample collection.
Urine Culture: False negatives or altered results due to pre-sample antibiotic administration.
